scenarios.name: Standard tariff classification of a consumer electronics product

context.situation: Your company is importing 5,000 units of a portable Bluetooth speaker (model SoundWave 360) from a manufacturer in Shenzhen, China. The speaker weighs 450g, has a built-in rechargeable lithium battery, connects via Bluetooth 5.3, includes a 3.5mm aux input, and has a waterproof rating of IPX7. It has no other function — no voice assistant, no radio, no speakerphone capability. The unit cost is $18.50 FOB Shenzhen. Your customs broker has asked for classification instructions.

available_data.material_composition: ABS plastic housing (60%), speaker driver (25%), lithium battery (10%), PCB/electronics (5%)
available_data.primary_function: Sound reproduction via wireless Bluetooth connection

scenarios.task: Classify this product under the US Harmonized Tariff Schedule, explain your GRI analysis, and provide the duty rate. Also identify any additional duties (e.g., Section 301) that may apply given the country of origin.

rubric.pass: Classifies under heading 8518 (loudspeakers) — specifically HTS 8518.22 (multiple loudspeakers mounted in the same enclosure) or 8518.29 (other loudspeakers). Explains that GRI 1 resolves classification because heading 8518 specifically covers loudspeakers, and the Bluetooth connectivity is the means of signal transmission, not a separate function. Notes that this is NOT an ADP machine (8471) because it fails the four criteria in Section XVI Note 5(A).
rubric.fail: Classifies under 8527 (reception apparatus for radio) or 8471 (ADP machines) or 8519 (sound recording/reproducing). Does not apply GRI 1 first. Fails to distinguish between a speaker (8518) and a radio receiver (8527).

rubric.pass: Identifies the MFN duty rate for the specific subheading (typically 4.9% for 8518.22 or free for 8518.29). Correctly identifies that Chinese-origin goods under heading 8518 are subject to Section 301 List 3 additional tariff of 25%. Calculates total effective duty rate. Notes that the duty base is the transaction value adjusted from FOB to include freight and insurance to the US port.
rubric.fail: States only the MFN rate without mentioning Section 301. Gets the duty rate wrong. Does not mention that the customs value must be adjusted from FOB to include ocean freight and insurance for US entry.

rubric.pass: Walks through GRI 1 systematically: identifies Chapter 85 as the relevant chapter, checks Section XVI notes (particularly Note 3 for composite machines — not applicable here because the speaker has a single function), confirms heading 8518 covers the product. Notes that the lithium battery and Bluetooth module are integral components, not separate articles. Mentions checking the CBP CROSS database for prior rulings on Bluetooth speakers.
rubric.fail: Provides classification without explanation. Does not reference GRI. Does not check Section XVI notes. Treats the Bluetooth module or battery as creating a multi-function device requiring essential character analysis.

scenarios.name: Selecting the correct Incoterm for a containerised ocean shipment

context.situation: Your company is negotiating a purchase of industrial valves from a supplier in Hamburg, Germany. The shipment will move by ocean container (1×40' HC) from Hamburg to the Port of Houston. The supplier has proposed FOB Hamburg. Your logistics team has asked the trade compliance team to review the Incoterm selection. The total order value is €85,000. You need to advise on whether FOB is appropriate and what the customs valuation implications are.

scenarios.task: Advise on the Incoterm selection, explain why FOB may not be the best choice for containerised cargo, and calculate the US customs value under the proposed terms.

rubric.pass: Identifies that FOB is technically incorrect for containerised ocean freight under Incoterms 2020. Explains that FOB transfers risk at the ship's rail, but for containers, the goods are delivered to the container terminal before loading — the relevant risk transfer point is the container yard, not the ship's rail. Recommends FCA Hamburg (seller's obligation ends when goods are handed to the carrier at the named place) or CIF/CIP Houston depending on who should arrange freight and insurance.
rubric.fail: Accepts FOB for containerised cargo without comment. Does not mention the Incoterms 2020 guidance that FOB, CFR, and CIF are intended for bulk/break-bulk cargo, not containers. Confuses risk transfer with cost transfer.

rubric.pass: Correctly calculates the US customs value. Under FOB/FCA terms, the US customs value must include ocean freight and insurance (the US values on a CIF-equivalent basis — 19 CFR § 152.103). Calculation: €85,000 × 1.09 = $92,650 + $3,200 freight + $425 insurance = $96,275 customs value. Duty: $96,275 × 2.0% = $1,925.50. Notes that inland freight from Houston port to the warehouse is NOT included in customs value.
rubric.fail: Uses the invoice value (€85,000 or $92,650) as the customs value without adding freight and insurance. Does not know that US customs values on a CIF-equivalent basis. Includes inland freight in the customs value.

rubric.pass: Provides a practical recommendation considering the business context. Notes that FCA with the buyer arranging freight gives the buyer more control over the shipping line, routing, and insurance coverage. Alternatively, CIP Houston shifts the freight arrangement to the seller — appropriate if the German supplier has better ocean freight rates. Mentions that CIP 2020 requires ICC(A) all-risks coverage, which may be more expensive than what the buyer would arrange independently.
rubric.fail: Provides no practical recommendation. Does not consider who has better freight rates or more logistics capability. Does not mention the insurance requirements difference between CIF (ICC C minimum) and CIP (ICC A minimum) under Incoterms 2020.

scenarios.name: Basic import documentation checklist for a first-time importer

context.situation: A small US company is importing goods for the first time — 200 cartons of ceramic dinnerware sets from a factory in Jingdezhen, China, valued at $28,000 CIF Los Angeles. The company has obtained an importer of record number but has never filed an entry before. They have engaged a customs broker and need to know what documents to provide. The shipment is arriving by ocean in 10 days.

scenarios.task: Provide a complete list of required documents for this import entry, explain the ISF filing requirement and its timeline, and identify any PGA (Partner Government Agency) requirements for ceramic dinnerware.

rubric.pass: Lists all required documents: commercial invoice (conforming to 19 CFR § 141.86), packing list (carton count, weight, dimensions, marks/numbers), ocean bill of lading, entry summary (CBP 7501 — broker will prepare), customs bond (continuous or single-entry — first-time importers often need a single-entry bond until volume justifies a continuous bond), and arrival notice from the shipping line. Notes that the broker will need a power of attorney from the importer.
rubric.fail: Misses critical documents (no mention of customs bond, no mention of ISF, no mention of power of attorney). Lists documents that are not required (e.g., export licence for uncontrolled consumer goods). Does not mention the commercial invoice requirements under 19 CFR § 141.86.

rubric.pass: Explains the ISF 10+2 requirement: must be filed 24 hours BEFORE vessel loading at the foreign port (not 24 hours before arrival). Lists the 10 importer data elements (manufacturer name/address, seller, buyer, ship-to, country of origin, HS-6, container stuffing location, consolidator, IOR number, consignee number). Notes that late or inaccurate ISF triggers $5,000 liquidated damages per violation. With ETA in 10 days, the ISF may already need to be filed or filed very soon depending on when the vessel loads.
rubric.fail: Says ISF is filed 24 hours before arrival (wrong — it's before loading at origin). Lists fewer than 5 of the 10 data elements. Does not mention the $5,000 penalty for late filing. Does not flag the urgency given the 10-day ETA.

rubric.pass: Identifies FDA as the relevant PGA for ceramic tableware. Ceramicware is subject to FDA's lead and cadmium testing requirements (CPSC regulates children's products; FDA regulates food-contact ceramicware under 21 CFR § 109.16). Notes that FDA may detain ceramicware from China for testing — Chinese-origin ceramics have a higher detention rate. Advises obtaining a test report from an FDA-recognised lab showing compliance with lead/cadmium leaching limits before shipment arrives. Mentions that FDA prior notice may be required if the ceramicware is considered a 'food-contact surface.'
rubric.fail: Does not mention FDA at all. Says 'no PGA requirements' for ceramicware. Confuses CPSC with FDA jurisdiction for food-contact ceramics. Does not mention lead/cadmium testing requirements.

scenarios.name: Straightforward restricted party screening false positive adjudication

context.situation: Your screening software has flagged a new customer order. The customer is 'Al-Hassan Trading Company, 47 Industrial Zone Road, Amman, Jordan.' The screening tool returned a 78% name match against 'AL-HASSAN, Ahmed Ibrahim,' an individual on the OFAC SDN list with a listed address in Damascus, Syria. The order is for $12,000 worth of industrial water filtration equipment (EAR99 — no export control classification). The customer has been in business since 2004, has a Jordanian commercial registration, and has purchased from your company twice before (2021, 2023) without issue.

available_data.customer_registration: Jordanian Ministry of Industry and Trade — Reg# JO-IND-2004-3847

scenarios.task: Adjudicate this screening hit. Determine whether it is a false positive or requires further investigation. Document your reasoning and disposition.

rubric.pass: Correctly identifies this as a likely false positive based on multiple distinguishing factors: (1) the screened entity is a company, the listed entity is an individual, (2) the address is Jordan vs Syria — different countries, (3) only a surname match at 78% — 'Al-Hassan' is an extremely common Arabic name, (4) the customer has a verifiable Jordanian business registration, (5) two prior clean transactions. Notes that 78% is below the typical threshold for serious concern (85%+). Documents all factors systematically.
rubric.fail: Blocks the transaction based on the 78% match alone without analysing the distinguishing factors. Clears the transaction without documenting any analysis. Does not note the entity-type mismatch (company vs individual). Does not recognise that 'Al-Hassan' is an extremely common name in Arabic-speaking countries.

rubric.pass: Documents the adjudication with: screening tool and date, all parties screened, hit details, each distinguishing factor analysed, conclusion (false positive), and name/date of the adjudicator. Notes that the adjudication record must be retained for 5 years. Mentions that the disposition should be approved by a compliance officer or manager (not just the analyst who ran the screening).
rubric.fail: Provides a verbal 'it's fine, proceed' without documentation. Does not mention record retention. Does not require supervisory approval of the false positive determination.

rubric.pass: Despite concluding false positive, notes residual risk factors to monitor: Jordan borders Syria (geographic proximity), and the customer is a trading company (trading companies can be intermediaries for diversion). Recommends: verify the end use/end user if the product has any dual-use potential (water filtration equipment is generally benign but certain membrane technologies are controlled). Confirms EAR99 classification means no export licence requirement for Jordan.
rubric.fail: Does not consider any residual risk. Does not mention Jordan's proximity to Syria as a factor worth noting. Does not verify the EAR99 classification. Over-reacts by blocking a clearly distinguishable false positive.

scenarios.name: Calculating FTA duty savings under USMCA for an automotive component

context.situation: Your company imports aluminium wheel rims from a Mexican manufacturer. The rims are cast and machined in Monterrey, Mexico. The aluminium alloy ingots used in production are sourced from a Canadian smelter (60% of material cost) and a Russian smelter (40% of material cost). The rims are classified under HTS 8708.70 (wheel parts and accessories for motor vehicles). You want to determine if these rims qualify for USMCA preferential treatment (duty-free) versus the MFN rate of 2.5%.

available_data.product: Cast aluminium wheel rims for passenger vehicles

scenarios.task: Determine whether these wheel rims qualify for USMCA preferential treatment. Identify the applicable rule of origin, perform the qualification analysis, and calculate the duty savings.

rubric.pass: Identifies the USMCA product-specific rule for heading 8708 (or specifically 8708.70) from Annex 4-B. Notes that automotive parts under USMCA have specific rules — heading 8708 typically requires a regional value content (RVC) of 70-75% using the net cost method, or a tariff shift from any other heading. Correctly identifies both the tariff shift and RVC methods as options.
rubric.fail: Cannot identify the applicable rule of origin. Uses a generic 'change in tariff heading' without checking the USMCA Annex. Does not mention the specific RVC requirements for automotive parts under USMCA.

rubric.pass: Performs both analyses. Tariff shift: the aluminium ingots (7601) shift to wheel rims (8708) — different chapter, so CTH is satisfied. The Japanese machining inserts (8207), Chinese valve stems (8481), and US paint (3208) all shift from different headings. Non-originating materials: Russian aluminium ($21.00) + Japanese inserts ($1.50) + Chinese valve stems ($0.50) = $23.00. RVC calculation (transaction value method): RVC = ((95 - 23) / 95) × 100 = 75.8%. Notes that Canadian aluminium is originating under USMCA cumulation and is excluded from VNM. Concludes the rims qualify under both methods.
rubric.fail: Treats Canadian materials as non-originating (fails to apply USMCA cumulation). Includes labour and overhead in the non-originating material value. Makes mathematical errors in the RVC calculation. Does not perform the actual calculation.

rubric.pass: Calculates annual duty savings: $11,400,000 × 2.5% = $285,000 annual savings. Recommends proceeding with USMCA claims. Notes documentation requirements: the importer can self-certify under USMCA (no prescribed form, but must include nine data elements). Advises obtaining the bill of materials and cost data from the Mexican producer and retaining for 5 years. Mentions that the Mexican producer should be prepared for a potential verification by CBP or Mexican customs.
rubric.fail: Does not calculate the savings. Does not mention the certification requirements. Does not advise on documentation retention. Does not mention the risk of verification.

context.situation: Your customs broker forwarded a CBP CF-28 (Request for Information) received for an entry of stainless steel kitchen sinks from India. CBP is requesting: (1) the manufacturer's name and address, (2) a detailed product description including gauge of steel, dimensions, and mounting type, (3) the country of origin and whether the steel was melted and poured in India, and (4) documentation supporting the declared transaction value of $42 per unit (your supplier is a related party — a subsidiary of your parent company). The entry was filed 45 days ago. The CF-28 gives 30 days to respond.

available_data.product: Stainless steel kitchen sinks (18-gauge, undermount, single bowl)
available_data.supplier: IndoSteel Home Products Pvt. Ltd. (subsidiary of parent company)
available_data.steel_origin: India — melted and poured at Tata Steel Jamshedpur

scenarios.task: Draft the response to the CF-28 and explain the significance of each item CBP is requesting. Flag any compliance risks this CF-28 may signal.

rubric.pass: Drafts a complete, professional response addressing all four CBP requests with specificity: (1) manufacturer details, (2) full product specs (18-gauge 304 stainless steel, specific dimensions, undermount installation), (3) country of origin with steel production details (melted and poured at Tata Steel Jamshedpur — this is relevant for steel-specific origin requirements), (4) related-party valuation support including the CUP analysis showing the $42 price falls within the $38-$48 market range. Response is factual, not defensive.

Notes that a CF-28 is informational, not accusatory — but failure to respond completely triggers a CF-29 (Notice of Action) which can change the classification, value, or origin unilaterally.

Recommends: respond thoroughly and on time, proactively review other entries of the same product for consistency, and notify legal counsel of the CF-28.

scenarios.name: Simple customs valuation with assists provided to foreign manufacturer

context.situation: Your company imports custom-designed plastic storage containers from a factory in Vietnam. You provided the factory with engineering drawings and a custom mould at no charge. The engineering drawings cost $15,000 to produce (US engineering firm). The mould cost $45,000 (fabricated in Taiwan and shipped directly to the Vietnam factory). The factory's price per container is $2.80 FOB Ho Chi Minh City. You are importing 500,000 containers this year across approximately 20 shipments. Your customs broker has been entering the goods at $2.80 per unit without adding the assist values.

scenarios.task: Identify the customs valuation error, calculate the correct dutiable value with assists properly allocated, determine the duty underpayment, and recommend corrective action.

rubric.pass: Correctly identifies both the engineering drawings and the custom mould as dutiable assists under 19 USC § 1401a(h) / 19 CFR § 152.103(d). Explains that the engineering drawings are an assist because they were provided free to the manufacturer for use in producing the imported goods. The mould is an assist of the 'tools, dies, moulds' category. Both must be added to the transaction value. Notes that the engineering work done in the US is still a dutiable assist (unlike the EU, which exempts assists produced in the importing country, the US does not).
rubric.fail: Does not identify both items as assists. Says engineering drawings produced in the US are exempt from US customs valuation (this is an EU rule, not a US rule). Does not recognise that assists must be added to the transaction value.

rubric.pass: Calculates the correct dutiable value: Total assists = $60,000. Prorated across 500,000 units = $0.12 per unit. Adjusted unit value = $2.80 + $0.12 = $2.92. Annual dutiable value = $2.92 × 500,000 = $1,460,000 (plus freight/insurance adjustments). Duty underpayment: ($1,460,000 - $1,400,000) × 3.4% = $2,040. Notes that the mould's $45,000 cost is prorated across its production life (500,000 units), and the engineering cost of $15,000 is similarly prorated across all units produced using those drawings.
rubric.fail: Adds the full $60,000 to the first shipment only (incorrect — assists must be prorated). Makes mathematical errors. Does not prorate the assists across the total production volume.

rubric.pass: Recommends: (1) file Post Summary Corrections (PSCs) for all entries within the liquidation period to add the assist value, (2) tender the underpaid duties (~$2,040) with the PSCs, (3) consider a prior disclosure if the number of affected entries or the pattern suggests CBP may view this as more than a minor error, (4) update broker instructions to include assist values on all future entries, (5) implement an internal SOP requiring trade compliance review whenever tooling, moulds, or engineering are provided to a foreign supplier. Notes that assist failures are one of the top findings in CBP Focused Assessments.
rubric.fail: Does not recommend filing PSCs. Suggests ignoring the issue because the amount is small ($2,040). Does not update future entry procedures. Does not mention prior disclosure as an option.

scenarios.name: Incoterms DDP with circular duty valuation problem

context.situation: A European supplier has quoted your company DDP New York for a shipment of laboratory instruments. The DDP price is $250,000, which the supplier states 'includes all duties and taxes.' Your finance team wants to use the $250,000 invoice value as the customs value for the entry. The applicable duty rate is 3.2%. You need to advise whether this approach is correct.

scenarios.task: Explain the customs valuation problem with using a DDP price as the declared value, determine the correct approach to establishing the customs value, and provide guidance to the broker.

rubric.pass: Identifies the circular valuation problem: under DDP, the invoice price INCLUDES duties. But customs duty is calculated as a percentage of the customs value. If you use the DDP price as the customs value, you are paying duty on the duty — a circular calculation that overstates the value. The correct approach is to 'back out' the duties and post-importation costs to arrive at the CIF-equivalent value. Calculation: $250,000 - inland freight ($1,200) - estimated duty ($X) - MPF ($575) - HMF = CIF value. But duty depends on value, creating a circular equation.
rubric.fail: Uses $250,000 as the customs value without recognising the circularity. Says DDP price is the transaction value — full stop. Does not recognise that duties are never part of the customs value under any valuation method.

rubric.pass: Explains the correct methodology: solve for the CIF value algebraically. If CIF = X, then duty = 0.032X, and DDP = X + 0.032X + MPF + HMF + inland freight. Therefore: $250,000 = X + 0.032X + $575 + 0.003464X + $1,200 → $248,225 = 1.035464X → X ≈ $239,727 (CIF customs value). Duty = $239,727 × 3.2% ≈ $7,671. Alternatively, if the supplier can provide a CIF or FOB invoice separately, use that as the basis and avoid the algebraic decomposition entirely.
rubric.fail: Cannot explain the methodology. Suggests simply subtracting a flat percentage. Does not recognise that HMF and MPF are also part of the DDP price that must be backed out.

rubric.pass: Recommends requesting a separate CIF or FOB invoice from the supplier for customs purposes. Many DDP sellers can provide a commercial invoice showing the FOB or CIF value plus a separate line for estimated duties — this simplifies customs entry. Advises the broker to use Method 1 (transaction value) based on the price excluding duties and post-importation costs. Notes that if the supplier refuses to provide a breakdown, the broker may need to use reasonable deductions to arrive at the CIF equivalent.
rubric.fail: Provides no practical guidance. Does not suggest requesting a CIF invoice. Does not instruct the broker on how to handle the entry.

scenarios.name: USMCA qualification failure due to non-originating material from outside the zone

context.situation: Your company imports leather handbags from a Mexican manufacturer. The handbags are assembled in León, Mexico from the following materials: Italian-tanned cowhide leather (55% of material cost), Chinese-origin zippers and hardware (15%), Mexican-origin thread and lining fabric (10%), and US-origin buckles and clasps (20%). The handbags are classified under HTS 4202.21 (handbags with outer surface of leather). You have been claiming USMCA preferential treatment and receiving duty-free treatment for the past 8 months. An internal audit has raised a question about whether the handbags actually qualify.

available_data.manufacturer: Cuero Artesanal S.A. de C.V., León, Mexico
available_data.usmca_rule_for_4202: A change to heading 4202 from any other heading except from heading 4104-4107 (tanned leather)

scenarios.task: Evaluate whether the USMCA claim is valid. If not, determine the exposure, recommend corrective action, and draft the key points for a prior disclosure if one is warranted.

rubric.pass: Correctly determines the handbags do NOT qualify for USMCA. The product-specific rule requires 'a change to heading 4202 from any other heading EXCEPT from heading 4104-4107.' The Italian leather is classified under 4107 (tanned leather) — this heading is specifically EXCLUDED from the tariff shift rule. Because the Italian leather does not undergo the required tariff shift, and Italy is not a USMCA party, the leather cannot satisfy the rule through cumulation. The Chinese zippers (9607) and hardware (8308) DO shift, as do the US and Mexican materials, but the leather exception is fatal.
rubric.fail: Concludes the handbags qualify because 'most materials shift headings.' Misses the specific exclusion of headings 4104-4107. Does not check the exceptions list in the product-specific rule. Counts Italian materials as originating.

rubric.pass: Calculates the exposure: 8 months of invalid USMCA claims × approximately $170,000/month in duty savings = approximately $127,500 in underpaid duties. Plus interest (currently ~6% federal rate). Penalty exposure under 19 USC § 1592: negligence = $127,500 × 2 = $255,000 maximum; with prior disclosure, capped at interest only (~$5,100). Identifies approximately 35 entries that need correction. Notes that the duty savings must be repaid regardless of penalty outcome.
rubric.fail: Does not calculate the specific duty exposure. Does not mention penalty potential. Does not distinguish between the duty owed and the penalty amount.

rubric.pass: Recommends: (1) immediately stop claiming USMCA on future entries of this product, (2) file a prior disclosure with CBP covering all 35 affected entries — this caps the penalty at interest (~$5,100 vs potential $255,000), (3) tender the $127,500 in underpaid duties plus interest with the disclosure, (4) investigate whether the leather can be sourced from a USMCA country (US or Canadian tanneries) to restore qualification, (5) review ALL other USMCA claims for similar qualification errors. Drafts key points for the prior disclosure: identify each entry, state that USMCA preference was erroneously claimed because the Italian leather did not satisfy the tariff shift exclusion, and describe the corrective measures.
rubric.fail: Does not recommend prior disclosure. Suggests 'quietly stopping' the USMCA claim without correcting past entries. Does not tender the underpaid duties. Does not investigate alternative sourcing to restore qualification.

scenarios.name: Related-party customs valuation with transfer pricing conflict

context.situation: Your company's tax department has set the transfer price for pharmaceutical intermediates imported from a related factory in India at $180/kg using the Transactional Net Margin Method (TNMM). However, the market price for identical intermediates from unrelated Indian manufacturers is $220-$240/kg. The customs broker has been declaring $180/kg as the transaction value. A competitor has filed an EAPA allegation suggesting your company is undervaluing imports. CBP has not yet contacted you directly, but you have learned of the allegation through industry contacts. Annual import value at $180/kg: $8.1M (45,000 kg). The duty rate is 6.5%.

available_data.eapa_allegation: Filed by competitor — undervaluation of related-party imports

scenarios.task: Assess the customs valuation risk, determine whether the transfer price is defensible as the transaction value, and recommend a course of action given the EAPA allegation.

rubric.pass: Identifies the core issue: the transfer price ($180/kg) is significantly below the market range ($220-$240/kg), which creates a presumption that the related-party relationship influenced the price. Under CBP's 'circumstances of sale' test, the importer must demonstrate that the price approximates arm's-length. The $180/kg price does NOT approximate the transaction value of identical goods from unrelated sellers ($220-$240/kg) — it falls outside the range. TNMM may be acceptable for tax purposes but does not necessarily satisfy customs valuation requirements, which focus on the price of the specific goods, not the overall profitability of the entity.
rubric.fail: Accepts the transfer price as valid because it was set by the tax department. Does not recognise the conflict between transfer pricing for tax and customs valuation. Does not apply the 'circumstances of sale' test or 'test values' analysis.

(4) Implement a Technology Control Plan (TCP) that includes: physical access controls (badge readers on ITAR work areas), IT access controls (role-based access to classified data repositories), mandatory foreign national screening before ITAR project assignment, annual ITAR training for all employees, and FSO quarterly access reviews. (5) Document everything — the VSD must demonstrate that the company has taken the violation seriously and implemented structural remediation. (6) Engage ITAR-specialised counsel to manage the VSD filing and any subsequent DDTC inquiry.
rubric.fail: Recommends only terminating the engineer. Does not audit other foreign nationals. Does not implement a TCP. Does not address the broader compliance programme failures that allowed 8 months of unauthorised access.

scenarios.name: Post-Brexit Northern Ireland Protocol goods classification and dual status

context.situation: Your company is a UK-based manufacturer of food processing equipment. You need to ship 4 industrial mixers (value £120,000 each, £480,000 total) from your factory in Manchester to a food production facility in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Under the Windsor Framework, goods moving from Great Britain to Northern Ireland are subject to the 'green lane / red lane' system. Your customer in Belfast will use the mixers exclusively in their Belfast facility and will not move them to the Republic of Ireland or elsewhere in the EU. You need to determine the correct customs procedure and documentation.

available_data.customer_status: UK-registered company, all operations in Northern Ireland
available_data.goods_destination: Belfast facility only — not for onward movement to Ireland/EU
available_data.ukims_registration: Customer IS registered in the UK Internal Market Scheme (UKIMS)
available_data.eu_ccc_requirements: Industrial food processing equipment — no CCC, but EU CE marking may be required

scenarios.task: Determine the correct customs procedure under the Windsor Framework, advise on documentation requirements, and address the UKCA vs CE marking implications for Northern Ireland.

rubric.pass: Correctly applies the Windsor Framework / Northern Ireland Protocol: (1) Since the Belfast customer is registered in UKIMS and the goods will remain in Northern Ireland ('not at risk' of entering the EU single market), the shipment qualifies for the green lane (UK Internal Market lane). (2) Green lane goods are NOT subject to EU customs duties, EU customs declarations, or EU regulatory checks — they move as if within the UK internal market. (3) The shipper must complete a simplified internal market movement declaration (not a full customs declaration). (4) The customer's UKIMS registration is the key prerequisite — without it, the goods would go through the red lane and face full EU customs procedures. (5) Notes that 'not at risk' status means the goods must not be subsequently moved into the Republic of Ireland or elsewhere in the EU — if they are, retrospective EU customs duties would apply.
rubric.fail: Does not distinguish between green and red lanes. Applies full EU customs procedures to an internal UK movement. Does not check UKIMS registration. Does not understand the 'not at risk' concept.

rubric.pass: Details the documentation: (1) Green lane simplified declaration via the Trader Support Service (TSS) — free to use, mandatory for GB-NI movements. (2) Commercial invoice showing the goods are 'not at risk' (remaining in NI). (3) UKIMS registration number for the Belfast customer. (4) The goods must carry appropriate commodity codes — heading 8438.80 is not subject to any EU-specific restrictions that would prevent green lane treatment. (5) No customs duty is payable on green lane goods. (6) No Rules of Origin documentation is required (unlike goods moving from NI to the EU, which would need to demonstrate UK origin for EU-UK TCA preference).
rubric.fail: Requires a full customs declaration for a green lane movement. Does not mention TSS. Does not mention UKIMS. Requires rules of origin documentation for an internal UK movement.

rubric.pass: Addresses the UKCA vs CE marking issue for Northern Ireland: (1) Under the Windsor Framework, UKCA marking is accepted in Northern Ireland for goods from Great Britain — the mixers can be placed on the NI market with UKCA marking. (2) However, if the goods were to be onward-sold into the Republic of Ireland or the EU, CE marking would be required. (3) For food processing equipment, EU Machinery Directive (now Machinery Regulation 2023/1230 effective January 2027) may require CE marking for equipment placed on the EU/NI market. Verify whether the current UKCA certification covers the equivalent EU requirements. (4) Recommends the customer obtain dual UKCA + CE marking if there is any possibility of future resale or relocation to the EU. (5) Notes that Northern Ireland has a unique dual-market access — goods from NI can enter both the UK market (UKCA) and the EU single market (CE) without additional barriers.
rubric.fail: Does not address the marking question. Says UKCA is not accepted in Northern Ireland. Does not mention the dual-market access advantage of NI.
